title: About
text:
I am currently a sophomore at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln double majoring in sports media and communications and advertising and public relations. I am from Junction City, Kansas but am currently based in Lincoln, Nebraska.
As an avid sports fan I take pride in looking deeper into the game and gaining knowledge from stats. With my coursework at UNL I have learned how to take apart stats and find the story behind the numbers. I look forward to continue gaining knowledge in the analysis side of sports.

title: About
text:
I am currently a sophomore at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln double majoring in sports media and communications and advertising and public relations. I am from Junction City, Kansas but am currently based in Lincoln, Nebraska.
As an avid sports fan I take pride in looking deeper into the game and gaining knowledge from stats. With my coursework at UNL I have learned how to take apart stats and find the story behind the numbers. I look forward to continue gaining knowledge in the analysis side of sports.

title: Do more steals mean more wins?
text:
Stealing bases is something that has been seen in college baseball for close to 70 years and has proven to have many benefits. Over time, it has become a strategic tool used to advance runners. It is typically used in a “small ball” sense with a focus on gaining runs through smaller calculated plays like bunts rather than normal hits. It is also seen as a major way to disrupt another team’s rhythm and boost your own team’s morale, creating a more energetic and fast-paced game. Stealing bases is the key to getting runners in scoring position and can make a real difference in close games. The real question is, do these stolen bases and extra runs really put teams over the edge and give them the win? This blog will analyze some of the top teams in college baseball this season to truly see if more steals means more wins.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
steals <- read_csv("baseball steals 2025 - Sheet1.csv")




Code
topsteals <- steals |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarize(
    AvgSB = mean(SB)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(AvgSB)) |>
  top_n(10)
topsteals |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    AvgSB = "Total Team Steals"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "The Virgina Military Institute Keydets lead the charge.",
    subtitle = "Take a look at the 10 teams dominating the bases."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
tab_source_note(md("**By**: Keegan Smith | **Source:** NCAA")) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#a71f23"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "VMI (SoCon)")
  )|>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   )








The Virgina Military Institute Keydets lead the charge.


Take a look at the 10 teams dominating the bases.


Team
Total Team Steals




VMI (SoCon)
164


Wofford (SoCon)
104


Mount St. Mary's (MAAC)
93


Southern U. (SWAC)
88


Georgetown (Big East)
84


Texas Southern (SWAC)
83


Northeastern (CAA)
81


Longwood (Big South)
79


Alcorn (SWAC)
76


George Mason (Atlantic 10)
76



By: Keegan Smith | Source: NCAA








In just 30 games the Virginia Military Institute Keydets managed to steal 164 bases, putting them far above every other Division I team this season. From the start of the season to April 4, 2025, the Keydets averaged 5.466 steals per game. Wofford comes in a not so close second place with 104 steals and the rest of the teams trail farther behind with less than 100 stolen bases on the season. Continuing this season after 37 games VMI is still at the top of the leaderboard with 184 stolen bases. The other top 10 teams have also continued their outstanding performance and remained in the top 10.


Code
set.seed(1234)
stealsconference <- steals |> 
  mutate(Team = gsub("(FL)", "FL", Team, fixed=TRUE)) |>
  mutate(Team = gsub("(NY)", "NY", Team, fixed=TRUE)) |>
  mutate(Team = gsub("(PA)", "PA", Team, fixed=TRUE)) |>
  mutate(Team = gsub("(OH)", "OH", Team, fixed=TRUE)) |> 
  mutate(Team = gsub("(CA)", "CA", Team, fixed=TRUE)) |>
  separate(Team, into = c("Team", "Conference"), sep = "\\(") |>
  mutate(Conference = gsub(")", "", Conference)) |>
  separate(`W-L`, into = c("Wins", "Losses", "Ties"), sep = "-") |>
  mutate(Wins = as.numeric(Wins))




Code
moststeals <- stealsconference |>
  filter(SB > 80)
ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=stealsconference, 
    aes(x=SB, y=Conference), color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=moststeals, 
    aes(x=SB, y=Conference), color="#009CDE") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = moststeals,
    aes(x=SB, y=Conference, label = Team)
  ) +
  labs(
    x="Total stolen bases this season", 
    y="Conference", 
    title="The Power 5 conferences are not so powerful when it comes to steals.", 
    subtitle="Many of the leading teams with stolen bases are from smaller conferences.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By: Keegan Smith"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









When you think of powerhouse teams in baseball, your mind typically goes to a school in one of the Power 5 conferences however, this is not the case when looking at the statistics for stolen bases. Of the top 10 teams with the most stolen bases, not a single one of them is from the Power 5. The Southern Conference (SoCon), Southwestern Athletic Conference (SWAC), Coastal Athletic Association (CAA), Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference (MAAC), and the Big East are all standouts when it comes to stolen bases. Each of these conferences has at least one team with more than 80 steals so far this season while the Power 5 doesn’t have any teams in this range.


Code
wins <- stealsconference |>
  filter(
    str_trim(Team) == "VMI" |
      str_trim(Team) == "Wofford" |
      str_trim(Team) == "Mount St. Mary's" |
      str_trim(Team) == "Georgia" |
      str_trim(Team) == "Arkansas"|
      str_trim(Team) == "Tennessee" |
      str_trim(Team) =="LSU" |
      str_trim(Team) == "Clemson"
  )

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=stealsconference, aes(x=Wins, y=SB), color= "lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=wins, aes(x=Wins, y=SB), color="#009CDE") +
  geom_text_repel(data=wins, aes(x=Wins, y=SB, label=Team)) + 
  labs(
    x="Wins", 
    y="Stolen Bases", 
    title="You win some, you lose some, but do you steal some?", 
    subtitle="The top teams in the nation are at the bottom of the leaderboard for stolen bases.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By: Keegan Smith"
    )+
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Looking at the highest ranked teams this season such as Arkansas, Georgia, and Clemson although they have the most wins, they are average at best when it comes to stolen bases. The same could be said when looking at the teams with the most steals, they are sitting near the middle of the pack when it comes to the number of wins they have this season.
After researching and looking at the data it can be said that having more stolen bases does not make that much of an impact on the number of wins a team has throughout a season. Although stealing does put runners in scoring position they are often left on base, not leading to an extra run or even a win. Overall, stolen bases are not one of the key deciding factors in winning or losing a game.

title: Who should be Nebraska’s next libero?
text:
text text text


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(waffle)
library(ggalt)


Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggalt':
  method                  from   
  grid.draw.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobHeight.absoluteGrob ggplot2
  grobWidth.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobX.absoluteGrob      ggplot2
  grobY.absoluteGrob      ggplot2


Code
library(ggtext)
vballplayers <- read.csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/ncaa_womens_volleyball_players_2124.csv")
neb24 <- vballplayers |>
  filter(season == "2024", team == "Nebraska")




Code
sets <- c("Laney Choboy"=121, "Olivia Mauch"=122)
 waffle(sets, 
        rows = 10, 
        title="Number of Sets Played", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 set", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "white")
        )+
   labs(
    x = "1 square = 1 set",
    title="Stacking up the sets and the stats", 
    subtitle="The defensive specialists battled for playing time in the 2024 season",
    caption="Source: NCAA | Graphic by Keegan Smith") + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  )









text?


Code
digs <- c("Laney Choboy"=185, "Olivia Mauch"=196)
waffle(digs/2, 
        rows = 5, 
        title="Total Digs", 
        xlab="1 square = 5 digs", 
        colors = c("black", "red")
        )+
  labs(
    x = "1 square = 2 digs",
    title="Digging deep and breaking down defensive dominance", 
    subtitle="Mauch's extra playing time let her rack up a few more digs",
    caption="Source: NCAA | Graphic by Keegan Smith") + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  )









text text text


Code
noberg <- neb24|>
  filter(name != "Bergen Reilly")
lr <- neb24 |>
  filter(name == "Lexi Rodriguez")
lc <- neb24|>
  filter(name == "Laney Choboy")
om <- neb24 |>
  filter(name == "Olivia Mauch")
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=noberg, aes(x=reorder(name, assists), weight=assists), fill="#ededed") +
  geom_bar(data=lc, aes(x=reorder(name, assists), weight=assists), fill="red") +
  geom_bar(data=om, aes(x=reorder(name, assists), weight=assists), fill="black") +
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Assists", 
    title="Stepping up to set it up", 
    subtitle="The setter being out of play leaves other players to set up attackers to finish the play.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By: Keegan Smith"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









more text text text


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=neb24, 
    aes(y=reorder(name, aces), x=aces, xend=s_err),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    title="Serving up drama: aces vs oopsies", 
  subtitle = "Comparing <span style = 'color:green;'>service aces</span> and <span style = 'color:red;'>service errors</span> from the 2024 season.",
  y="", x="Serves"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )


Warning: Using the `size` aesthetic with geom_segment was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use the `linewidth` aesthetic instead.









stacked bar chart??
final text text text

title: Smith's Sports Site
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1

✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

library(waffle)
library(ggalt)

Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggalt':
  method                  from   
  grid.draw.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobHeight.absoluteGrob ggplot2
  grobWidth.absoluteGrob  ggplot2

library(ggtext)
vballplayers <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/ncaa_womens_volleyball_players_2124.csv")

Rows: 23601 Columns: 31
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (8): team, conference, name, class, position, height, hometown, high_sc...
dbl (23): season, number, gp, gs, s, kills, errors, total_attacks, hit_pct, ...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



neb24 <- vballplayers |>
  filter(season == "2024", team == "Nebraska")


head(neb24)

# A tibble: 6 × 31
  season team    conference name  number class position height    gp    gs     s
   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>      <chr>  <dbl> <chr> <chr>    <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1   2024 Nebras… Big Ten    Lexi…      8 Sr.   L/DS     5-5       36     0   122
2   2024 Nebras… Big Ten    Rebe…      5 Jr.   MB       6-4       35    34   109
3   2024 Nebras… Big Ten    Andi…     15 So.   MB       6-3       34    34   114
4   2024 Nebras… Big Ten    Mais…      7 Jr.   L/DS     5-6        9     0    13
5   2024 Nebras… Big Ten    Kenn…      9 Sr.   S        6-0       35     0   112
6   2024 Nebras… Big Ten    Merr…     13 Sr.   OH       6-4       36    36   122
# ℹ 20 more variables: kills <dbl>, errors <dbl>, total_attacks <dbl>,
#   hit_pct <dbl>, assists <dbl>, aces <dbl>, s_err <dbl>, digs <dbl>,
#   r_err <dbl>, block_solos <dbl>, block_assists <dbl>, b_err <dbl>,
#   pts <dbl>, bhe <dbl>, srv_att <dbl>, trpl_dbl <dbl>, ret_att <dbl>,
#   tb <dbl>, hometown <chr>, high_school <chr>



sets <- c("Laney Choboy"=121, "Olivia Mauch"=122)
 waffle(sets, 
        rows = 10, 
        title="Number of Sets Played", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 set", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "white")
        )+
   labs(
    x = "",
    title="Playing time upping the stats", 
    subtitle="Mauch had more playing time to rack up a few more digs",
    caption="Source: NCAA | Graphic by Keegan Smith") + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  )









 digs <- c("Laney Choboy"=185, "Olivia Mauch"=196)
waffle(digs/2, 
        rows = 5, 
        title="Total Digs", 
        xlab="1 square = 5 digs", 
        colors = c("black", "red")
        )+
  labs(
    x = "",
    title="Playing time upping the stats", 
    subtitle="Mauch had more playing time to rack up a few more digs",
    caption="Source: NCAA | Graphic by Keegan Smith") + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  )









noberg <- neb24|>
  filter(name != "Bergen Reilly")
lr <- neb24 |>
  filter(name == "Lexi Rodriguez")
lc <- neb24|>
  filter(name == "Laney Choboy")
om <- neb24 |>
  filter(name == "Olivia Mauch")
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=noberg, aes(x=reorder(name, assists), weight=assists), fill="#ededed") +
  geom_bar(data=lc, aes(x=reorder(name, assists), weight=assists), fill="red") +
  geom_bar(data=om, aes(x=reorder(name, assists), weight=assists), fill="black") +
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Assists", 
    title="Stepping up to set it up", 
    subtitle="The setter being out of play causes other players to set up attackers to finish the play.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By: Keegan Smith"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=neb24, 
    aes(y=reorder(name, aces), x=aces, xend=s_err),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    title="Service aces vs service errors", 
  subtitle = "Comparing <span style = 'color:green;'>service aces</span> and <span style = 'color:red;'>service errors</span> from the 2024 season.",
  y="", x="Serves"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )
